results.title: KOK 28mm hand cranked projector
results.brief_description: In 1912, the popular Pathé Kok camera and projector arrived, which used the more standard 28mm film and cast a 30-inch picture.
results.description:
28mm hand crank projector designed by Pathe. Designed for home use, the Pathe KOK projector uses non-flammable cellulose acetate safety film and an electric light. The projector is powered by a crank handle. Contains: projector, hand crank, metal cover, 2 x metal reels.
Sticker on reel says “The property of Visual Education Centre, Education Dept. Victoria”
See video of same model (modified) of projector in use: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SG9Nvly1UB4
Was ACMI Lending Collection/ACMI Collection in 2014 audit - NR says unclear, but should keep.
28 mm gauge metal projector on wooden base.Object functions.

results.title: Kojak. Vol. 01
results.brief_description: A sink full of bloodied knives and the bodies of two young girls are found. Based on a true story, this movie length pilot has Theo, “I aint rich but at least I dress well”, detective Kojak in charge as the largest man hunt in New York ensues. A simple black boy is arrested and charged. It appears though that the confession was forced, the integrity of the commended and respected policemen in question. A court struggle drags on as Kojak sets out to discover the real murderer. Drugs, grime, poverty and hard hitting detective work spice up this television police drama. Telly Savalas plays the strong and masculine Kojak who shows his sensitive side, as all good policemen do.

results.title: Koestler on creativity
results.creator_credit: Robert Vas and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Arthur Koestler discusses some of the mental processes underlying the creative act, conscious and unconscious. He defines the creative act as occurring through the “bisociation” of two existing ideas to create something not seen before. Compares the methods of the artist and scientist to show their similarities.

results.title: Koalas: the bare facts
results.creator_credit: Paul Scott, Chris Oliver, Bruce Moir and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Koalas today are a species in trouble, threatened with extinction as the Australian suburbs spread. They are extremely vulnerable because they are dependent on eucalyptus forest and must feed on gum leaves for an average of five hours per day in order to survive. This film takes a dramatic and often amusing look at the plight facing this extraordinary animal and the lengths to which some people will go in order to help. If you think koalas are cute and cuddly animals who just sit round eating gum leaves all day, this film will surprise you.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Scott, Chris Oliver, Bruce Moir and Film Australia

results.title: Koalas: Out on a Limb
results.brief_description: A documentary that examines the situation of koalas in the wild. Healthy koalas in the Australian bush are a rare sight these days and there are several different factors that are contributing towards the rapid decline in the population. One of the main factors is venereal disease which causes many females to become infertile.

results.title: Koalas and lyre birds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Two in the Bush”.
The naturalist and author, Gerald Durrell, watches koala being caught and transferred from one reserve to another to save them from starvation. We also see lyrebirds in Sherbrooke Forest and visit a wild life sanctuary on the Gold Coast of Queensland.

results.title: Koalas and co
results.creator_credit: Rob McCubbin, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Louise Jonas
results.brief_description: Non-narrated film which makes use of natural sound to observe some of the Australian animals that live in trees. Koalas, fruit bats, tree frogs and primitive looking lizards are observed in detailed close-ups, highlighting their adaptations to live in trees. Filmed at the Royal Melbourne Zoo, Melbourne Botanic Gardens and Healesville Sanctuary. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
